overview: Subsequent to the previous fiscal note, the bill was amended by the House Committee on Consumer Protection & Commerce to specify that budget summaries must contain all required information without referring to other documents and to change the effective date to July 1, 3000, to encourage further discussion (HB70_HD1_HSCR253_). Testimony reveals significant debate over provisions that remove an association's 'good faith' defense and shift the burden of proof for compliance to the association. Opponents fear this will lead to increased litigation, while supporters argue it is necessary for enforcement (HB70_HD1).
economic_impact: While the direct fiscal impact on the state remains negligible, new testimony details potential economic effects on private condominium associations and owners. Opponents argue the bill could expose associations to costly and frivolous litigation, potentially increasing insurance premiums (HB70_HD1). Conversely, supporters provide evidence of existing financial harm to owners from mismanagement that the bill aims to prevent, citing an 829% (HB70_HD1) increase in insurance premiums resulting in special assessments over $5,200 (HB70_HD1) and reserve fund deficits of $14,783 (HB70_HD1) per unit.
policy_impact: The House Committee on Consumer Protection & Commerce amended the measure, changing its effective date to July 1, 3000, to facilitate further debate on its more contentious aspects (HB70_HD1_HSCR253_). The primary policy debate, clarified in new testimony, centers on the removal of the 'good faith' defense for non-compliant associations and the shifting of the legal burden of proof to the association in enforcement actions. Opponents contend this shift is inconsistent with general legal principles, while supporters view it as a critical tool for ensuring compliance with financial disclosure laws (HB70_TESTIMONY_CPC_01-30-25_).
updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: This fiscal note is updated to reflect amendments made by the House Committee on Consumer Protection & Commerce, which changed the bill's effective date to July 1, 3000 (HB70_HD1_HSCR253_). New testimony has been incorporated, providing specific examples of potential economic impacts on private associations and owners, including fears of increased litigation costs versus evidence of existing financial burdens like special assessments exceeding $5,200 (HB70_HD1). The policy impact section is also updated to detail the specific nature of the ongoing legislative debate regarding legal defenses and the burden of proof.
